<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_allocate:
```c
int metal_softirq_allocate(int num)
{
	int irq_base;

	if ((metal_softirq_avail + num) >= metal_softirq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "No more available soft irqs\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_base = metal_softirq_avail;
	irq_base += metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_softirq_avail += num;
	return irq_base;
}
```

explanation: Rule 17.2 concerns functions calling themselves directly or indirectly. In metal_softirq_allocate the only function-like operations are the call to the logging macro (metal_log) and any functions referenced/registered via the IRQ controller declaration. These are the only code fragments that could introduce an indirect call path back to metal_softirq_allocate. The remaining code in metal_softirq_allocate is simple data checks and arithmetic (accesses to metal_softirq_avail, metal_softirq_num, metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base and returning irq_base) and does not perform any function calls that could cause recursion, so they do not need investigation for Rule 17.2. Similarly, standalone variable declarations are not relevant to recursive-call checking.
